page.title: 18EAST MEON - BUILDINGS
page.content: Although the village was mentioned in the Domesday Book of 1085,there was probably a settlement here in earlier times.Today the village shows evidence of its long history in its buildings many of which like the church (where Roundhead soldiers are supposed to have been buried) and the Almshouses are of made of local flints,often with the corners squared in stone.Other buildings are of red brick,some are half timbered.Many of the buildings have been whitewashed and some are thatched.The Court House dates from the Middle Ages.One in the High Street is Georgian in appearance.There are a number of Victorian farm workers' cottages and even some late 20th Century council housing.Many buildings show evidence of the continuous adaptations, re-building and changes that have occured over the years.
